;;2018 年 12 月 5 日，瑞士苏黎世的一栋办公楼内可见发光的 Google 徽标。REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/档案照片;
;

;大型科技公司将面临欧盟的新规定，在明年欧盟重要投票之前，在其平台上明确标记政治广告、谁支付了费用、支付了多少费用以及哪些选举是针对的

;

;欧盟国家和欧洲议会立法者周一晚间同意的新政治广告规则将迫使 Alphabet 旗下的谷歌等社交媒体集团;(GOOGL.O);，元平台更加透明和负责。

;

;违反新欧盟规定可能会受到惩罚广告提供商将被处以年营业额 6% 的罚款。

;

;该规定将禁止第三国实体在选举或公投前三个月内在欧盟赞助政治广告，并禁止投放带有个人形象的广告

;

;“新规则将使外国行为者更难传播虚假信息并干扰我们的自由和民主进程，”一直领导的欧洲议会议员桑德罗·戈齐 (Sandro Gozi) 说。在一份声明中称，这一进程已在欧洲议会进行。

;

;欧盟国家和欧盟立法者在讨论了欧盟委员会去年提出的法规草案的细节后达成协议。

;

;所有在线政治广告都将在在线广告存储库中提供。

;

;“我们还为下一次欧洲议会选举及时确保了跨国竞选活动的有利环境，”Gozi 说。

;

;欧洲议会将于明年 6 月举行选举，许多人担心投票前的虚假信息和外国干预。

;

;欧盟范围内的规则将在发布后 18 个月内适用预计将于 2025 年生效。

;

;在此之前，规范跨境政治广告（包括针对欧洲政党和政治团体）的非歧视性提供的措施将已经到位2024 年欧洲议会选举。

;

; Tue, 07 Nov 2023 19:55:03 +0800 Israel readies for Gaza City push as UN decries month of Middle East “carnage“https://reuters.com/article/israel-palestinians/israel-readies-for-gaza-city-push-as-un-decries-month-of-middle-east-carnage-idUSKBN32202G

;;周二（11 月 7 日），汗尤尼斯市以色列空袭的幸存者从他家的废墟中走出来，表示以色列“向平民展示了他们的威力”，而几名家人仍被困在废墟下。此编辑包含图形图像。;
;

;以色列给仍被困在新包围的加沙城内的平民周二提供了四个小时的时间离开，逃离的居民说他们经过了坦克，可能会开始袭击它.

;

;以色列表示，其军队已经包围了加沙城，该飞地的 230 万人口中有三分​​之一居住在加沙城，并准备在消灭一个月前袭击以色列城镇的哈马斯伊斯兰分子的行动中很快对加沙城发起猛攻。

;

;战争于 10 月 7 日爆发，根据以色列统计，武装分子冲破加沙周围的围栏，杀害了 1,400 名以色列人（其中大部分是平民），并绑架了 200 多人。此后，以色列对哈马斯控制的加沙地带发动袭击，根据当地卫生官员的统计，造成 10,000 多人死亡，其中约 40% 是儿童。

;

;“大屠杀已经持续了整整一个月。持续不断的痛苦、流血、破坏、愤怒和绝望，”联合国人权专员沃尔克·特克在开始对该地区的访问时发表声明说，在此期间他将访问来自埃及的拉法过境点，这是援助的唯一路线.

;

;“侵犯人权是这场升级的根源，而人权在寻找摆脱这种痛苦漩涡的出路中发挥着核心作用。”

;

;以色列为居民提供了一个窗口周二上午 10:00 至下午 2:00 离开加沙城。居民表示，以色列坦克大多在夜间移动，以色列军队主要依靠空中和炮击为地面推进扫清道路。

;

;“为了您的安全，请抓住下一次向南移动的机会瓦迪加沙，”军方宣布，指的是一分为二的湿地。

;

;“这是我一生中最危险的旅行。我们近距离看到了坦克。我们看到了腐烂的身体部位。我们看到了死亡，”居民 Adam Fayez Zeyara 发布了一张自己在离开加沙城的路上的自拍照。

;

;虽然以色列的军事行动集中在加沙北半部，但南部也受到了攻击。巴勒斯坦卫生官员表示，周二早些时候，以色列对加沙南部城市汗尤尼斯和拉法发动的两次单独空袭，造成至少 23 人死亡。

;

;“我们是平民，”获救的艾哈迈德·阿耶什 (Ahmed Ayesh) 说。汗尤尼斯 (Khan Younis) 一座房屋的废墟中，卫生官员称，那里有 11 人死亡。 “这就是所谓的以色列的勇敢，他们向平民、屋内的婴儿、屋内的孩子和老人展示了他们的威力和力量。”

;

;当他说话时，房子里的救援人员用手试图解救一名被埋在腰间的废墟中的女孩。

;

;总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡表示，以色列将考虑“;加沙地带的战术小停顿;"，为让人质离开或援助进入而战斗，但再次拒绝了日益强烈的停火呼吁。

;

;以色列军方表示，他们已经占领了加沙地带北部的一处武装分子大院，并准备袭击隐藏在地下隧道中的武装分子。它发布的视频显示，部队使用推土机挖土并推倒墙壁。

;

;以色列军方称，以色列飞机袭击了几名哈马斯武装分子，他们将自己困在加沙城圣城医院附近的一栋建筑内。

;

;以色列和哈马斯都拒绝了越来越多的停止战斗的呼吁。以色列表示应首先释放人质。哈马斯表示，当加沙受到攻击时，它不会释放他们，也不会停止战斗。

;

;双方平民遭受苦难的恐怖故事在​​过去一个月里使世界舆论两极分化，而且没有任何缓和的迹象。

;

; >;

;在以色列谢法因姆，阿维海·布罗杜奇 (Avihai Brodutch) 描述了哈马斯之后 31 天的痛苦;从距离加沙约三公里（2 英里）的基布兹 Kfar Aza 绑架了他的妻子;和三个孩子。

;

;“我的孩子们，他们还很小，而且他们没有对任何人做错事，”他谈到他 10 岁的女儿奥弗里和八岁的儿子尤瓦尔和四岁的乌利亚时说道。

;

;自上周以来，数百名持有外国护照的加沙人已获准通过拉法过境点进入埃及。但绝大多数加沙人被困在加沙地带内，那些得以逃脱的人描述了他们离开亲人时所遭受的痛苦。

;

;“这只是一部不断重复的恐怖电影，” 31 岁的巴勒斯坦裔美国人苏珊·贝塞索 (Suzan Beseiso) 上周成功离开加沙前往埃及，他在开罗告诉路透社。 “没有睡眠。没有食物。没有水。你不断地从一个地方疏散到另一个地方。”

;

;她自己的逃亡充满了;以色列在撤离路线上进行轰炸的危险;，她说。

;

;内塔尼亚胡表示，全面停火将阻碍他的行动美国总统乔·拜登周一与内塔尼亚胡通过电话讨论了这种暂停，重申了他对以色列的支持，同时强调必须这样做白宫表示，保护平民。

;

;华盛顿支持以色列关于哈马斯将利用全面停火重新集结的说法。但许多国家和机构表示，需要立即停火，以帮助处于危险之中的加沙人。

;

;飞地正在成为“;儿童墓地;”，联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯周一表示。国际组织表示，医院无法应对伤员，食物和清洁水即将耗尽，援助物资的运送远远不够。

;

;“我们需要立即实现人道主义停火。已经过去 30 天了。受够了。这现在必须停止，”几位联合国领导人发表声明说。周一，各国机构;。

;

;以色列军方周一发布了坦克穿过被炸毁的街道和部队徒步行进的视频。首席军事发言人丹尼尔·哈加里少将表示，部队正在追捕哈马斯战地指挥官，以削弱武装分子“进行反击”的能力。

;

;有人担心这场持续了一个月的冲突可能会蔓延到其他战线，包括以色列占领的约旦河西岸和与黎巴嫩的北部边境，这两个地区的骚乱激增，达到多年来最严重的程度。

;

;在被占领的约旦河西岸，巴勒斯坦卫生部表示自10月7日以来，周二共有163名巴勒斯坦人被以色列军队杀害，今年以来被杀人数达到371人。

; Tue, 07 Nov 2023 19:55:03 +0800 Belgium“s traditional horseback fishers see climate change in their netshttps://reuters.com/article/climate-change-belgium-fishing/belgiums-traditional-horseback-fishers-see-climate-change-in-their-nets-idUSKBN3220RC
;;2023-11-07T11:39:46Z;
;

;在比利时远西海岸一个寒冷的冬日，冈瑟·凡布鲁 (Gunther Vanbleu) 骑着他的驮马沿着沙滩行驶，进入浅水区。

;

;Vanbleu 的亮黄色风衣在海浪的衬托下显得格外突出，在水下，他的驮马（以其强大的后躯为特征）沿着沙滩拉动链条，引起震动，虾跳入张开的网中。

;

;沿海村庄 Oostduinkerke 是世界上最后一个仍在进行马背虾捕捞的地方 - 如今，马背虾捕捞已成为联合国教科文组织认可的数百年传统，而不是商业企业.

;

;渔民靠近沿海水域，使他们成为气候变化如何改变北海生态系统的第一线见证人。

;

;“我们的虾捕捞量减少了比以前多了。但我们也有更多以前没有见过的织鹬和动物种类，它们是随着海水变暖而来自大西洋的，”范布卢告诉路透社。织鳅是一种有毒的小鱼，它们往往会在沙子里挖洞，只露出眼睛。

;

;据美国宇航局称，过去几十年来，海洋吸收了人类造成的全球变暖的 90%。在北海，自 1991 年以来，表面温度每十年上升约 0.3 摄氏度。

;

;温度上升扰乱了小型骑马捕鱼社区的传统季节。

;

;"当我们看到第一场雪时，这个季节就结束了；12 月，雪就结束了。现在，我们看不到雪了。”渔民艾迪·德赫斯特 (Eddy D'Hulster) 说。

;

;虽然虾的数量会在短期变化中出现波动，例如热浪过后，渔民和科学家报告称，鸬鹚鱼和鱿鱼的数量有所增加，这些鱼和鱿鱼传统上生活在更南部的地方，但现在已向北移动到比利时温暖的水域。

;

;“对于某些物种，我们看到了更高的丰度，例如鸬鹬和鱿鱼。根特大学海洋生态研究员伊利亚斯·塞穆里 (Ilias Semmouri) 表示，在水温较高的情况下，“鱿鱼就像墨鱼一样”。

;

;其他物种的情况更糟。自 20 世纪 80 年代以来，北海鳕鱼数量急剧下降，;科学家将;归因于海水温度上升和过度捕捞。

;

;气候变化正在导致鱼类种群发生不可预测的变化，使得设定捕捞配额以可持续地管理海洋种群变得更加困难，科学主任汉斯·波莱特（Hans Polet）说。 ILVO，比利时佛兰德斯地区渔业研究所。

;

;“大自然不再像我们习惯的那样做出反应。系统中即将出现湍流，”波莱特说。 “它要去哪里？我不知道。我很担心，我真的很担心。”

;

; Tue, 07 Nov 2023 19:25:03 +0800 US Supreme Court mulls legality of domestic-violence gun curbshttps://reuters.com/article/usa-court-guns/us-supreme-court-mulls-legality-of-domestic-violence-gun-curbs-idUSKBN3220OX
;;2023-11-07T11:07:42Z;
;

;The US Supreme Court on Tuesday is set to weigh the legality of a ;federal law; that makes it a crime for people under domestic violence restraining orders to have guns in the latest major case to test the willingness of its conservative majority to further expand ;gun rights;.

;

;Oral arguments are scheduled in an appeal by President Joe Biden's administration of a lower court's ruling striking down the law - intended to protect victims of domestic abuse - as a violation of the US Constitution's Second Amendment right to "keep and bear arms."

;

;The New Orleans-based 5th US Circuit Court of Appeals concluded that the measure failed a stringent test set by the Supreme Court in a 2022 ;ruling; that required gun laws to be "consistent with the nation's historical tradition of firearm regulation" in order to survive a Second Amendment challenge.

;

;Advocacy groups for victims of domestic violence have warned of the grave danger posed by armed abusers, citing studies that show that the presence of guns increases the chances that an abused intimate partner will die.

;

;In a nation bitterly divided over how to address firearms violence including frequent mass shootings, the court's 6-3 conservative majority has taken an expansive view of the Second Amendment and has broadened gun rights in three landmark rulings since 2008.

;

;Its 2022 ruling in a case called New York State Rifle and Pistol Association v. Bruen recognized a constitutional right to carry a handgun in public for self defense, striking down a New York state law.

;

;The case involves Zackey Rahimi, a Texas man who pleaded guilty to illegally possessing guns in violation of the law at issue on Tuesday while he was subject to a restraining order for assaulting his girlfriend in a parking lot and later threatening to shoot her. Police found the guns while searching his residence in connection with at least five shootings.

;

;Violating the law initially was punishable by up to 10 years in prison but has since been raised to 15 years.

;

;A federal judge rejected Rahimi's Second Amendment challenge and sentenced him to more than six years in prison. The 5th Circuit in February ;set aside; Rahimi's conviction, concluding that although he was "hardly a model citizen," the law at issue was an "outlier" that could not stand under the new standard the justices announced in Bruen.

;

;Biden's administration has said the law should survive because of the long tradition in the United States of taking guns from people deemed dangerous.

;

;Supporters of Rahimi have argued that judges too easily issue restraining orders in an ;unfair; process that results in the deprivation of the constitutional gun rights of accused abusers.

;

;A ruling is expected by the end of June.

;

;Republicans who control the US House of Representatives said they do not expect to move forward this week on a stopgap funding measure to keep federal agencies open, even with a possible government shutdown just 10 days away.

;

;Instead, House Speaker Mike Johnson was due to present at least three options for a stopgap known as a continuing resolution, or "CR," to lawmakers at a closed-door Republican conference on Tuesday morning, the lawmakers said.

;

;Funding for government operations is due to expire on Nov. 17 unless Congress agrees on a temporary spending measure that President Joe Biden can sign into law before the deadline. Otherwise, federal agencies will have to close their doors for an indefinite period.

;

;But with this week already shortened by a Veterans Day observance on Friday, three Republican lawmakers who spoke on condition of anonymity said the House was unlikely to approve a CR this week. One lawmaker said a Republican policy of waiting three days before voting on legislation left little time to act this week.

;

;House Republicans are due to focus the agenda for the week on passing their own partisan appropriations bills for 2024.

;

;Another lawmaker said Republicans are considering at least three options for structuring a CR, including a "laddered" option that would assign separate deadlines in December and January by which time the House and Senate would hammer out compromise legislation on specific 2024 appropriations bills. Details were uncertain.

;

;Republicans will also consider a more conventional CR that would run to a Jan. 19, leaving December for lawmakers to work on appropriations bills and supplemental funding requests including Israel, Ukraine and other priorities.

;

;The lawmaker said a third option would be to negotiate with the Democratic-led Senate on a CR that can pass both chambers quickly.

;

;The House has passed seven of 12 appropriations bills for 2024 and will try to pass another two this week, aimed at funding transportation, housing and urban development; and financial services. The Senate has passed three appropriations bills in a package known as a minibus.

;

;While the Senate legislation enjoys strong bipartisan support, the House has passed only partisan Republican measures opposed by Democrats.

;

;Only one category of appropriations legislation, covering military construction and veterans benefits, has passed both chambers in markedly different forms.

;Ohio is the ;latest abortion battleground;, nearly a year and a half since the Supreme Court decision.

;

;Last year, abortion rights advocacy groups scored a series of victories by placing abortion-related referendums on the ballot, including in conservative states.

;

;They have doubled down on that strategy. In addition to Tuesday's amendment in Ohio that would enshrine abortion rights in the state constitution, similar ballot measures are advancing in several states for 2024, including swing states Arizona and Florida.

;

;Anti-abortion forces have campaigned against the Ohio amendment as too extreme, while abortion rights groups have warned that rejecting it would pave the way for a stringent ban to take effect.

;

;Ohio's Republican-controlled legislature previously approved a six-week limit, but the law is on hold pending the outcome of a legal challenge before the conservative state Supreme Court.

;

;Voters in August rejected a separate referendum, backed by Republicans, that would have raised the threshold to approve constitutional amendments - including Tuesday's ballot question - from 50% to 60%.

;

;In Virginia, all 40 seats in the Senate and 100 seats in the House of Delegates are on the ballot. Democrats hold a slim majority in the Senate, while Republicans have a narrow edge in the House.

;

;;Democrats have sought; to make abortion the top issue, warning that a Republican victory would lead to a ban. Republican Governor Glenn Youngkin has said he will pursue a 15-week abortion limit if Republicans take control of the legislature, a move he has characterized as a reasonable compromise that could offer a blueprint for Republicans in 2024.

;

;Republicans have focused on public safety, running advertisements claiming that Democrats would cut police funding and go easy on criminals. Some 40% of respondents in ;a September Reuters/Ipsos poll; said Republicans have the best approach to addressing crime, compared to 32% who picked Democrats on the issue.

;

;A Republican sweep would boost Youngkin's rising national profile; his political action committee ;has invested millions of dollars; in the legislative races. Some Republicans wary of Trump have floated Youngkin as a potential late entry to the 2024 presidential race, though the governor has said he has no plans for a White House run.

;

;Biden added his weight to the race last week, issuing endorsements for 16 Democrats running in competitive races for the state House and seven in the Senate, while sending out a fundraising plea to supporters.
